title: EPIC: Complete Parser for All Mermaid Diagram Types
description:

title: Implement intelligent error recovery and intent inference
description:
This is a KEY DIFFERENTIATOR from mermaid-js. Implement a multi-layer error recovery system in fm-parser that makes FrankenMermaid more forgiving and smarter when the user's intent is clear:

1. LEXER RECOVERY: On unexpected characters, skip to next recognizable token and report warning (not error). Collect all warnings and attach to IR as diagnostics.

2. PARSER RECOVERY: On syntax errors, attempt recovery strategies:
   a. Missing arrow type: 'A B' -> infer 'A --> B' (default arrow)
   b. Missing semicolons/newlines: best-effort line splitting
   c. Unclosed brackets/parens: auto-close at end of block
   d. Typos in keywords: fuzzy-match against known keywords (Levenshtein distance <= 2)
   e. Wrong diagram type prefix: detect from content if prefix is wrong/missing
   f. Mixed syntax: detect and handle mixing of e.g. flowchart and graph keywords

3. SEMANTIC RECOVERY: After parsing, fix semantic issues:
   a. Dangling edges (referencing non-existent nodes): auto-create placeholder nodes
   b. Duplicate node IDs: merge definitions, warn
   c. Circular subgraph containment: flatten with warning
   d. Invalid direction values: map to nearest valid direction

4. INTENT INFERENCE: For severely malformed input, try multiple diagram type parsers and pick the one with highest parse success ratio. Report: 'Parsed as flowchart (87% confidence, 2 warnings)'.

5. DIAGNOSTIC OUTPUT: Attach Vec<Diagnostic> to IR with severity (Error/Warning/Info), span, message, and suggestion. Renderers can display these as annotations.

This must NEVER panic or return Err for any input string -- always produce best-effort IR.

title: Implement robust diagram type auto-detection
description:
Build a multi-strategy diagram type detector in fm-parser that can identify the diagram type even when the header keyword is missing, misspelled, or ambiguous.

Strategies in order of precedence:
1. Explicit keyword match: 'flowchart', 'sequenceDiagram', 'classDiagram', 'stateDiagram-v2', 'gantt', 'pie', 'erDiagram', 'gitGraph', 'mindmap', 'timeline', 'journey', 'sankey-beta', 'C4Context', 'kanban', 'architecture-beta', 'block-beta', 'xychart-beta', 'quadrantChart', 'packet-beta', 'radar-beta', 'treemap', 'requirementDiagram'
2. Fuzzy keyword match: Levenshtein distance <= 2 from any known keyword
3. Content heuristic: scan for characteristic patterns (e.g., '--->' implies flowchart, 'participant' implies sequence, '||--o{' implies ER)
4. DOT detection: looks_like_dot() from dot_parser (digraph/strict/graph keywords)
5. Fallback: try parsing as flowchart (most permissive syntax)

Return: DetectedType { diagram_type: DiagramType, confidence: f32, method: DetectionMethod, warnings: Vec<Diagnostic> }

This complements the error recovery system -- together they ensure any text input produces a diagram.

title: Build SVG generation core with element primitives
description:
Create the SVG generation foundation in fm-render-svg/src/. Build a lightweight SVG builder (no heavy XML dependencies) that produces clean, minimal SVG output:

1. SvgDocument: Root element with viewBox, xmlns, responsive sizing. Methods: to_string(), to_writer(W: Write).

2. Element primitives: rect, circle, ellipse, line, polyline, polygon, path, text, tspan, g (group), defs, use, clipPath, marker.

3. Path builder: Fluent API for SVG path d-attribute. M/L/C/Q/A/Z commands. Supports absolute and relative coordinates.

4. Attribute system: Type-safe attributes (fill, stroke, stroke-width, transform, class, id, data-*). CSS class-based styling preferred over inline styles for themability.

5. Transform builder: translate, rotate, scale, matrix.

6. Text rendering: Multi-line text with tspan elements. Text measurement (estimated, since we don't have font metrics in Rust -- use character-count heuristic with configurable average character width).

7. Defs section: Reusable definitions for arrowhead markers, gradients, filters (drop shadows, blur).

Dependencies: None beyond std. This is a zero-dependency SVG builder. Output: String or streaming to io::Write.

title: Extract layout engine into fm-layout crate
description:
Extract mermaid_layout.rs (10,656 lines) and diagram_layout.rs (3,081 lines) into fm-layout/src/. This is the core graph layout engine implementing the Sugiyama layered graph layout algorithm.

5. Post-Processing: Cluster boundary computation with padding. Port resolution and attachment. Edge routing with waypoint generation. Quality scoring.

title: Implement superior cycle handling in Sugiyama layout
description:
This is THE core differentiator mentioned in the X thread. Mermaid-js handles cycles poorly. Our approach:

1. DETECTION: Tarjan's SCC algorithm to find all strongly connected components. Report cycle count, participants, and nesting depth.

2. MULTI-STRATEGY CYCLE BREAKING (user-configurable):
   a. GREEDY (current): Source/sink peeling. Fast, good for mostly-DAG graphs.
   b. DFS-BACK: Depth-first search, reverse back edges. Minimizes reversed edges.
   c. MINIMUM-FEEDBACK-ARC-SET: Approximation algorithm (NP-hard exact). Finds near-minimal set of edges to reverse. Better aesthetics for heavily cyclic graphs.
   d. CYCLE-AWARE: Don't break cycles at all -- render them as visible cycles with curved back-edges. This is the 'honest' approach that shows the user their cycles rather than hiding them.

3. BACK-EDGE RENDERING: For reversed edges in GREEDY/DFS/MFAS modes, provide metadata so renderers can draw them distinctly (dashed line, different color, reversed arrowhead) to communicate that these represent cycles.

4. CYCLE CLUSTER COLLAPSE: Option to collapse an entire SCC into a single 'cycle cluster' node that can be expanded. Reduces visual complexity for highly cyclic subgraphs.

5. QUALITY METRICS: Track number of reversed edges, total edge length increase from reversal, visual symmetry of cycle representation. Expose in LayoutStats.

Determinism: All strategies must be deterministic given identical input. Use stable sorting, break ties by node ID.

title: Implement force-directed layout algorithm
description:
Implement a deterministic force-directed (spring-electric) layout for diagrams that don't have a natural hierarchy. Used for: ER diagrams (entities with many-to-many relationships), architecture diagrams, generic graphs with no clear flow direction.

Algorithm: Fruchterman-Reingold variant with:
1. Repulsive forces: All node pairs push apart (inverse-square law). Use Barnes-Hut approximation O(n log n) for graphs > 100 nodes.
2. Attractive forces: Connected nodes pull together (Hooke's law / log-spring).
3. Cooling schedule: Start with high temperature, reduce per iteration. Use deterministic schedule (no RNG -- use hash-based initial positions).
4. Convergence: Stop when max displacement < threshold or iteration budget exhausted.
5. Overlap removal: Post-processing pass to ensure no node overlap.
6. Cluster awareness: Nodes in same IrCluster get extra attractive force.

Key: Deterministic initial placement using hash of node IDs (not random). Same input always produces same output. Iteration count configurable via LayoutConfig.

Output: Same DiagramLayout type as Sugiyama. Callers don't need to know which algorithm was used.
